title: Physics (PH)
description: Comprehensive GATE Physics assessment covering General Aptitude and Core Physics subjects. This assessment includes 10 aptitude questions (15% weight) and 55 core physics questions (85% weight) following the official GATE pattern.
whatIsDescription: GATE (Graduate Aptitude Test in Engineering) Physics is a national-level examination that primarily tests the comprehensive understanding of various undergraduate subjects in physics and related fields. This assessment follows the official GATE pattern with General Aptitude and Core Physics questions.

typicalCareers.title: Research Scientist
typicalCareers.description: Advanced physics research positions in academia and industry

typicalCareers.title: PhD Candidate
typicalCareers.description: Pursue higher studies in physics and related fields

typicalCareers.title: Physics Engineer
typicalCareers.description: Senior technical roles in physics-based technology and applications

whoShouldConsider: Students seeking admission to M.Tech/M.E programs in physics
Professionals looking for PSU jobs in physics sector
Researchers in physics and related fields
idealTraits: Good understanding of physical principles and phenomena

aptitude.title: General Aptitude Assessment
aptitude.description: Test your general aptitude including verbal ability, quantitative aptitude, and analytical reasoning skills. This section carries 15% weight in the total assessment.

questions.text: If GATE is coded as 3-1-20-5, then what is the code for EXAM?
questions.subject: Verbal Ability - Coding
questions.explanation: Using alphabetical position: E=5, X=24, A=1, M=13. Therefore EXAM = 5-24-1-13.

questions.text: A train travels at 60 km/hr for 2 hours and then at 80 km/hr for 3 hours. What is the average speed?
questions.subject: Numerical Ability - Average Speed
questions.explanation: Total distance = (60×2) + (80×3) = 120 + 240 = 360 km. Total time = 2 + 3 = 5 hours. Average speed = 360/5 = 72 km/hr.

questions.text: Which word is the odd one out: Circle, Triangle, Square, Rectangle, Sphere?
questions.subject: Logical Reasoning - Classification
questions.explanation: Sphere is a 3D object while all others are 2D shapes.

questions.text: Find the next number in the series: 2, 6, 12, 20, 30, ?
questions.subject: Numerical Ability - Series
questions.explanation: The differences are 4, 6, 8, 10, 12... (increasing by 2). So next term = 30 + 12 = 42.

questions.text: If 15% of a number is 45, what is 25% of that number?
questions.subject: Numerical Ability - Percentage

questions.text: Choose the word most similar in meaning to 'Meticulous':
questions.subject: Verbal Ability - Synonyms
questions.explanation: Meticulous means showing great attention to detail, which is synonymous with precise.

questions.text: A pie chart shows data for 5 categories. If one category represents 72°, what percentage does it represent?
questions.subject: Data Interpretation - Percentage
questions.explanation: Total degrees in circle = 360°. Percentage = (72/360) × 100 = 20%.

questions.text: If all roses are flowers and some flowers are red, then:
questions.subject: Logical Reasoning - Syllogism
questions.explanation: We can only conclude that some roses may be red, not that they must be or cannot be.

questions.text: The ratio of boys to girls in a class is 3:2. If there are 15 boys, how many students are there in total?
questions.subject: Numerical Ability - Ratio
questions.explanation: If boys:girls = 3:2 and boys = 15, then each part = 15/3 = 5. Total students = 5 parts = 5 × (3+2) = 25.

questions.text: Choose the grammatically correct sentence:

options.text: Each of the students have submitted their assignments.
Each of the students has submitted their assignment.
Each of the students have submitted his assignments.
Each of the student has submitted their assignment.

questions.subject: Verbal Ability - Grammar
questions.explanation: 'Each' is singular, so requires 'has' not 'have'. 'Their' is acceptable for singular indefinite pronouns in modern English.

core.title: Core Physics Assessment
core.description: Comprehensive assessment of core physics subjects including Classical Mechanics, Quantum Mechanics, Electromagnetism, Thermodynamics, Modern Physics, and related topics. This section carries 85% weight in the total assessment.

questions.text: What is the SI unit of electric field intensity?
questions.subject: Electromagnetism - Electric Field
questions.explanation: Electric field E = F/q = N/C. Also, E = V/d = V/m. Since V = J/C, both N/C and V/m are equivalent units.

questions.text: A particle moves in a circle of radius 2m with constant speed 4 m/s. What is its centripetal acceleration?
questions.subject: Classical Mechanics - Circular Motion
questions.explanation: Centripetal acceleration a = v²/r = 4²/2 = 16/2 = 8 m/s².

questions.text: The wave function of a particle is ψ(x) = A sin(kx). What does |ψ|² represent?
questions.subject: Quantum Mechanics - Wave Function
questions.explanation: According to Born's interpretation, |ψ|² represents the probability density of finding the particle at position x.

questions.text: For an ideal gas, which quantity remains constant in an isothermal process?
questions.subject: Thermodynamics - Processes
questions.explanation: Isothermal means constant temperature (iso = same, thermal = temperature).

questions.text: Calculate the de Broglie wavelength of an electron (m = 9.1×10⁻³¹ kg) moving with velocity 10⁶ m/s. (h = 6.6×10⁻³⁴ J·s)
questions.subject: Quantum Mechanics - Matter Waves

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a fundamental force in nature?
questions.subject: Modern Physics - Fundamental Forces
questions.explanation: Tension is a contact force arising from electromagnetic interactions between atoms. The four fundamental forces are gravitational, electromagnetic, weak nuclear, and strong nuclear.

questions.text: A convex lens of focal length 20 cm forms an image at 60 cm. What is the object distance?
questions.subject: Optics - Lens Formula
questions.explanation: Using lens formula: 1/f = 1/v - 1/u. Therefore 1/20 = 1/60 - 1/u, solving: 1/u = 1/60 - 1/20 = -1/30, so u = -30 cm (object side).

questions.text: What is the dimension of Planck's constant?
questions.subject: Mathematical Physics - Dimensions
questions.explanation: h = Energy/frequency = [ML²T⁻²]/[T⁻¹] = [ML²T⁻¹]. Also represents action (angular momentum).

questions.text: A spring with spring constant 100 N/m is compressed by 0.1 m. What is the potential energy stored?
questions.subject: Classical Mechanics - Energy
questions.explanation: Elastic potential energy U = ½kx² = ½ × 100 × (0.1)² = ½ × 100 × 0.01 = 0.5 J.

questions.text: What is the work function if photoelectrons are emitted when light of wavelength 400 nm is incident, but not for 500 nm?
questions.subject: Modern Physics - Photoelectric Effect
questions.explanation: E = hc/λ. For 500 nm: E = 2.48 eV (no emission). For 400 nm: E = 3.10 eV (emission occurs). Work function must be between these values.

questions.text: Maxwell's equations in vacuum include all EXCEPT:
questions.subject: Electromagnetism - Maxwell's Equations
questions.explanation: In vacuum, the fourth Maxwell equation is ∇×B = μ₀ε₀∂E/∂t (no current J). Option D is for a conductor, not vacuum.

questions.text: A particle in a 1D infinite potential well has energy proportional to:
questions.subject: Quantum Mechanics - Particle in a Box
questions.explanation: For infinite square well, En = n²π²ℏ²/(2mL²), so energy is proportional to n².

questions.text: The Stefan-Boltzmann law states that radiant power is proportional to:
questions.subject: Thermodynamics - Radiation
questions.explanation: Stefan-Boltzmann law: P = σAT⁴, where power radiated is proportional to the fourth power of absolute temperature.

questions.text: What is the magnetic field at the center of a circular loop of radius R carrying current I?
questions.subject: Electromagnetism - Magnetic Field
questions.explanation: For a circular current loop, magnetic field at center B = μ₀I/(2R).

questions.text: In Compton scattering, the scattered photon has:
questions.subject: Modern Physics - Compton Effect
questions.explanation: In Compton scattering, photon transfers energy to electron, resulting in lower energy (and thus lower frequency) for scattered photon.

questions.text: The Hamiltonian operator in quantum mechanics represents:
questions.subject: Quantum Mechanics - Operators
questions.explanation: The Hamiltonian operator Ĥ represents the total energy (kinetic + potential) of the system.

questions.text: Carnot engine efficiency depends on:
questions.subject: Thermodynamics - Heat Engines
questions.explanation: Carnot efficiency η = 1 - (T₂/T₁) depends only on the temperatures of hot source (T₁) and cold sink (T₂).

questions.text: The Fermi energy in a metal at T = 0 K represents:
questions.subject: Solid State Physics - Free Electron Model
questions.explanation: At absolute zero, electrons fill energy levels up to the Fermi energy EF, which is the highest occupied energy level.

questions.text: A particle moves with simple harmonic motion. Its velocity is maximum when:
questions.subject: Classical Mechanics - Oscillations
questions.explanation: In SHM, velocity is maximum at mean position (displacement = 0) where all energy is kinetic.

questions.text: The Pauli Exclusion Principle applies to:
questions.subject: Quantum Mechanics - Quantum Statistics
questions.explanation: Pauli Exclusion Principle states that no two fermions (half-integer spin particles) can occupy the same quantum state.

questions.text: What is the ground state energy of a quantum harmonic oscillator?
questions.subject: Quantum Mechanics - Harmonic Oscillator
questions.explanation: The ground state (n=0) energy of quantum harmonic oscillator is E₀ = ℏω/2, the zero-point energy.

questions.text: The first law of thermodynamics is expressed as:
questions.subject: Thermodynamics - Laws
questions.explanation: First law: dU = dQ + dW (with sign convention: work done on system is positive).

questions.text: Calculate the force between two point charges of 2 μC and 3 μC separated by 0.3 m in vacuum. (k = 9×10⁹ Nm²/C²)
questions.subject: Electromagnetism - Coulomb's Law

questions.text: Which of the following violates the Heisenberg uncertainty principle?
questions.subject: Quantum Mechanics - Uncertainty Principle
questions.explanation: Δx·Δp = 0 would mean both position and momentum are known exactly, violating the uncertainty principle.

questions.text: The refractive index of a medium is 1.5. What is the speed of light in that medium?
questions.subject: Optics - Refraction

questions.text: What is the SI unit of magnetic flux?
questions.subject: Electromagnetism - Magnetic Flux
questions.explanation: Magnetic flux Φ is measured in Weber (Wb), where 1 Wb = 1 T·m².

questions.text: In photoelectric effect, stopping potential is independent of:
questions.subject: Modern Physics - Photoelectric Effect
questions.explanation: Stopping potential depends on frequency (photon energy) and work function, but NOT on intensity.

questions.text: A projectile is fired at 45° to the horizontal. Its range is maximum when the angle is:
questions.subject: Classical Mechanics - Projectile Motion
questions.explanation: Maximum range occurs at 45° angle for projectile motion on level ground.

questions.text: The Rydberg formula is used to calculate:
questions.subject: Atomic Physics - Hydrogen Spectrum
questions.explanation: Rydberg formula: 1/λ = R(1/n₁² - 1/n₂²) gives wavelengths of hydrogen spectral lines.

questions.text: For an adiabatic process in an ideal gas, which relation is correct?
questions.subject: Thermodynamics - Adiabatic Process
questions.explanation: For adiabatic process (no heat exchange), PVᵞ = constant, where γ = Cp/Cv.

questions.text: The Bohr radius of hydrogen atom is approximately:
questions.subject: Atomic Physics - Bohr Model
questions.explanation: Bohr radius a₀ = 0.53 Å = 0.053 nm (since 1 Å = 0.1 nm).

questions.text: In Young's double slit experiment, fringe width is inversely proportional to:
questions.subject: Optics - Interference
questions.explanation: Fringe width β = λD/d, where d is slit separation. So β ∝ 1/d.

questions.text: The commutator [x̂, p̂x] in quantum mechanics equals:
questions.subject: Quantum Mechanics - Commutators
questions.explanation: Canonical commutation relation: [x̂, p̂x] = iℏ.

questions.text: A capacitor of 10 μF is charged to 100 V. The energy stored is:
questions.subject: Electromagnetism - Capacitance
questions.explanation: Energy U = ½CV² = ½ × 10×10⁻⁶ × (100)² = 0.05 J.

questions.text: The decay constant λ and half-life T₁/₂ are related as:
questions.subject: Nuclear Physics - Radioactivity
questions.explanation: Half-life relation: T₁/₂ = ln(2)/λ, therefore λ = ln(2)/T₁/₂.

questions.text: The work done in rotating a dipole of moment p from angle θ₁ to θ₂ in uniform field E is:
questions.subject: Electromagnetism - Electric Dipole
questions.explanation: Work done W = U₂ - U₁ = -pE cos θ₂ - (-pE cos θ₁) = pE(cos θ₁ - cos θ₂).

questions.text: Bose-Einstein condensation occurs for particles with spin:
questions.subject: Statistical Mechanics - Quantum Statistics
questions.explanation: Bose-Einstein condensation occurs for bosons, which have integer spin (0, 1, 2, ...).

questions.text: The Poynting vector represents:
questions.subject: Electromagnetism - EM Waves
questions.explanation: Poynting vector S = (E × B)/μ₀ represents electromagnetic energy flux (power per unit area).

questions.text: A particle in a central force field conserves:
questions.subject: Classical Mechanics - Central Forces
questions.explanation: In a central force field (F parallel to r), torque is zero, so angular momentum is conserved.

questions.text: The binding energy per nucleon is maximum for:
questions.subject: Nuclear Physics - Binding Energy
questions.explanation: Iron-56 has the highest binding energy per nucleon (~8.8 MeV), making it the most stable nucleus.

questions.text: For a particle on a ring, the angular momentum eigenvalues are:
questions.subject: Quantum Mechanics - Angular Momentum
questions.explanation: For particle on ring, Lz eigenvalues are mℏ with m = 0, ±1, ±2, ... (unrestricted integer).

questions.text: The entropy change in an irreversible process is:
questions.subject: Thermodynamics - Entropy
questions.explanation: For irreversible processes, entropy of the universe always increases (ΔS > 0).

questions.text: The cyclotron frequency depends on:
questions.subject: Electromagnetism - Charged Particles
questions.explanation: Cyclotron frequency ω = qB/m depends on charge-to-mass ratio (q/m) and magnetic field B.

questions.text: Resolving power of a microscope is proportional to:
questions.subject: Optics - Resolving Power
questions.explanation: Resolving power ∝ 1/λ. Shorter wavelengths give better resolution.

questions.text: The partition function Z in statistical mechanics is related to:
questions.subject: Statistical Mechanics - Partition Function
questions.explanation: Partition function Z connects to all thermodynamic quantities: F = -kT ln Z, U = -∂ln Z/∂β, S = k ln Z + U/T.

questions.text: The Lorentz force on a charged particle moving in EM fields is:
questions.subject: Electromagnetism - Lorentz Force
questions.explanation: Lorentz force: F = qE + q(v × B) = q(E + v × B).

questions.text: A rigid body has how many degrees of freedom in 3D space?
questions.subject: Classical Mechanics - Rigid Body
questions.explanation: Rigid body in 3D has 6 degrees of freedom: 3 translational + 3 rotational.

questions.text: The Dulong-Petit law relates to:
questions.subject: Solid State Physics - Specific Heat
questions.explanation: Dulong-Petit law: molar specific heat of solids ≈ 3R at high temperatures.

questions.text: In X-ray diffraction from crystals, Bragg's law is:
questions.subject: Solid State Physics - X-ray Diffraction
questions.explanation: Bragg's law for constructive interference: 2d sin θ = nλ.

questions.text: The Klein-Gordon equation describes:
questions.subject: Quantum Mechanics - Relativistic QM
questions.explanation: Klein-Gordon equation is the relativistic wave equation for spin-0 particles (scalar bosons).

questions.text: The Lagrangian L of a system is defined as:
questions.subject: Classical Mechanics - Lagrangian Formalism
questions.explanation: Lagrangian L = T - V, where T is kinetic energy and V is potential energy.

questions.text: Rutherford scattering is characteristic of:
questions.subject: Nuclear Physics - Scattering
questions.explanation: Rutherford scattering describes alpha particle scattering by Coulomb (electromagnetic) force from nucleus.

questions.text: For a p-n junction diode in forward bias, the depletion region:
questions.subject: Electronics - Semiconductor Devices
questions.explanation: In forward bias, the depletion region width decreases as majority carriers overcome the barrier.

questions.text: The Debye temperature is related to:
questions.subject: Solid State Physics - Lattice Dynamics
questions.explanation: Debye temperature θD characterizes lattice vibration spectrum and specific heat behavior at low temperatures.

questions.text: The Dirac equation predicts:
questions.subject: Quantum Mechanics - Relativistic QM
questions.explanation: Dirac equation naturally incorporates electron spin, predicts antimatter (positron), and explains fine structure of hydrogen spectrum.

results.title: GATE Physics Assessment Results
results.description: Your comprehensive GATE Physics assessment results with detailed analysis and recommendations for improvement.
